column4: do new files or files downloaded from the internet have executable permissions by default?
like, if i download a text file from a unix server that has the executable bit set, will that be preserved?
i'm pretty sure it wont
thats why we have to do chmod +x for .bin files
but i seem to be able to run scripts off the bat without chmoding them.. i havent changed the ssytem at all
you mean like running bash scripts and such? yeah, i dont think they have to be executables
I am just thinking about that dodgey openoffice "badbunny" worm.. it copys a script to an xchat directory
shell scripts do have to be set executable.. or you couldn't execute it
yes that is true, this is one of the reasons linux is so secure agains spyware/virii
er, .bin's are not shell scripts. .bin's are binary executables, and yes, they have to be chmodded +x before executing
perhaps shell scripts do as well... i cant remember heh
but the thing is, when you download a file, your linux system gives it permissions depening on which users downloads it (user accout, root, etc.) but it is never set executable by default
i am aware that a .bin generaly is a binary application file.. but shell scripts still need the executable bit set
will test that
ok, so shell scripts do need the executable bit
well, i made a ls.sh (containing only /bin/ls) on my webserver and set the exectuable bit. i then downloaded it to ubuntu and ran "/bin/bash ls.sh" this worked
although the executable bit is actually not preserved it seems
so the script ran without setting it executable?
if you type /bin/bash whatever.sh then yeah
